raw_comment: I noticed that no matter what the test scores show, legacy applicants have a higher rate of admission, and it appears that the best way a non-legacy student has to get into the elite college would be to come from a rich family. I wonder why legacy students have a higher admission rate, if a non-legacy student has a higher test score than it seems that they should have a better chance then a legacy student with a lower test score. This affects my community because there could be many students who have the potential to go to an elite college but might be waitlisted if there are many legacy students in that given year. A catchy headline could be "Do legacy students deserve an advantage"
ace_sentences: I noticed that legacy applicants have a higher admission rate than non-legacy applicants.
This is true no matter what the test scores show.
It appears that a non-legacy student has the best chance to enter an elite college if the student comes from a rich family.
I wonder why legacy students have a higher admission rate.
A non-legacy student can have a higher test score than a legacy student.
If a non-legacy student has a higher test score than a legacy student, then the non-legacy student should have a better chance of admission than the legacy student.
In my community, many students have the potential to go to an elite college.
If there are many legacy students in a given year, then some non-legacy students might be waitlisted.
The headline is: Do legacy students deserve an advantage?
